facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 222 of 1956 filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 222 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated December 8, 1953 of former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 55 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 8, 1953, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 55 of 1950.

facts.text: Appellant is Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh and Bhopal.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is by the Commissioner of Income-tax, Madhya Pradesh and Bhopal.

facts.text: Respondents are assessees Vyas Dotiwala.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are the assessees Vyas Dotiwala.

facts.text: Assessment years concerned are 1945-46 and 1946-47.

anchor.surface_text: the assessment years companycerned were 1945-46 and 1946-47.

facts.text: In or about July 1943, Deputy Commissioner, Amraoti evolved a scheme due to cloth difficulty.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in or about July 1943 when companysiderable difficulty was being felt about cloth, the Deputy Commissioner, Amraoti, evolved a scheme to solve that difficulty.

facts.text: Kisanlal Vyas and firm Edulji Framji Dotiwala undertook to finance the scheme without charging interest or profit.

anchor.surface_text: Under that scheme Kisanlal Vyas and a firm called Edulji Framji Dotiwala who have in these proceedings been referred to as Dotiwala, undertook to finance the scheme without charging any interest or profit

facts.text: Vyas and Dotiwala appointed as financiers and distributors of standard cloth for Amraoti town, camp and interior areas.

anchor.surface_text: and were appointed as financiers and also distributors of a variety of cloth called standard cloth for the town and camp of Amraoti and certain areas in the interior

facts.text: Assessees agreed to open account in Imperial Bank of India to finance cloth purchases.

anchor.surface_text: Vyas and Dotiwala, who as an association of persons are the assessees companycerned, agreed to open an account in the Imperial Bank of India to be operated by them out of which the purchases of the cloth were to be financed.

facts.text: Assessees to pay Deputy Commissioner value of consignment plus 6-1/4 per cent of ex-mill price on arrival.

anchor.surface_text: The orders for the cloth were to be placed by the Government with the mills and on the arrival of a companysignment of cloth, the assessees were to pay to the Deputy Commissioner, Amraoti, the value of the companysignment together with 6-1/4 per cent. of the ex-mill price.

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner to pay assessees 4-1/2 per cent of ex-mill price for contingent expenses not exceeding 3 per cent.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner would pay 4-1/2 per cent. of the ex-mill price to the assessees out of the amount paid by the latter as aforesaid for companytingent expenses of working the scheme. The scheme provided that the companytingent expenses were number to exceed 3 percent. of the ex-mill price.

facts.text: Cloth distributed through shop by assessees in Amraoti and through Tehsildars with Patils in interiors.

anchor.surface_text: The cloth companying to the hands of the assessees was to be distributed in Amraoti town and camp through a shop to be opened by the assessees and in the interiors of the area companycerned through Tehsildars with Patils under them.

facts.text: Distribution arrangement under control of Deputy Commissioner, who was responsible for sale proceeds from Tehsildars.

anchor.surface_text: The substance of the arrangement of distribution appears to have been that it would be entirely under the companytrol of the Deputy Commissioner who made himself responsible to the assessees for the sale proceeds receivable from the Tehsildars.

facts.text: Para 14 of scheme: Profits resulting from scheme to be utilised for charitable purposes decided by Deputy Commissioner in consultation with advisory committee.

anchor.surface_text: The most important provision in this scheme is para. 14 which is set out below. Profits resulting from the scheme shall be utilised for such charitable purposes as may be decided on by the Deputy Commissioner in companysultation with the advisory companymittee appointed to supervise the scheme.

facts.text: Books of assessees showed Rs. 34,737 for 1945-46 and Rs. 17,682 for 1946-47 as profits from scheme.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the books of the assessees showed Rs. 34,737/- for the assessment year 1945-46 and Rs. 17,682/- for the assessment year 1946-47 as profits earned in working the scheme.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed assessees to tax on the profits earned from scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer assessed the assessees to tax on the profits so earned.

facts.text: Assessees contended before ITO that income exempt under s. 4(3)(i-a) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment orders made by this officer would appear to show that the only point urged by the assessees before him against the assessment was that the income was exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Commissioner companyfirmed the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held profits not income of assessees and set aside assessment orders.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held-that the assessees had objected... The Appellate Tribunal agreed with the companyten- tion of the assessees that they were number liable to be taxed on the profits because these did number form their income... In this view of the matter the Tribunal set aside the orders of assessment.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court under s. 66(1).

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on the application of the revenue authorities the Tribunal referred the following question to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Act

facts.text: High Court answered referred question in negative.

anchor.surface_text: On that reference the High Court held... In this view of the matter the High Court answered the question framed, in the negative.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on October 3, 1958 by Sarkar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. October 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR J.-

facts.text: Respondents did not appear in the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents have number appeared in this appeal.

facts.text: Assessees claimed before Tribunal that income not theirs and exempt under s. 4(3)(i-a), as per letter dated January 22, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held-that the assessees had objected to the assessment before the Income-tax Officer on two grounds, namely, that the income was Dot the income of the assessees and that the income was exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a , as appeared from their letter dated January 22, 1947.

delivered on a reference under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act. The appeal is by the Commissioner of Income-tax,

anchor.surface_text: On that reference the High Court held that under the charging section in the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, namely, s. 4, it was necessary for the revenue authorities to prove that the assessees received or should be deemed to have received income

concepts.interpretation: Covers income that accrued; High Court erred by focusing only on receipt/deemed receipt; profits accrued as income of assessees from business.
concepts.unlisted_description: Charging section defining total income including accrued income

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts of this case any income accrued to Messrs. Vyas and Dotiwala as the result of their associating themselves as financiers in the scheme for the distribution of standard cloth and, if so whether such income was assessable in their hands.

concepts.interpretation: Profits from working the scheme accrued to assessees as their income despite control by Deputy Commissioner and agreement to devote to charity.

concepts.interpretation: Assessees carried on business by financing and distributing cloth under scheme, despite government control; profits theirs unless otherwise.
concepts.unlisted_description: Tax principle determining if activity constitutes business generating taxable income

issues.text: Whether on the facts of this case any income accrued to Messrs. Vyas and Dotiwala as the result of their associating themselves as financiers in the scheme for the distribution of standard cloth and, if so whether such income was assessable in their hands.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts of this case any income accrued to Messrs. Vyas and Dotiwala as the result of their associating themselves as financiers in the scheme for the distribution of standard cloth and, if so whether such income was assessable in their hands.

issues.text: Whether the income was exempt from taxation under s. 4(3)(i-a) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment orders made by this officer would appear to show that the only point urged by the assessees before him against the assessment was that the income was exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

issues.text: Whether the assessees carried on business by working the scheme despite control by the Deputy Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: the assessees had agreed to do business in a certain manner. The fact that the Deputy Commissioner guaranteed the payment

arguments.claim: The income was exempt from taxation under s. 4(3)(i-a) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment orders made by this officer would appear to show that the only point urged by the assessees before him against the assessment was that the income was exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

arguments.court_reasoning: Scheme not carried on behalf of any religious or charitable institution; use of income irrelevant once profit made by assessees.

arguments.claim: The income was not the income of the assessees.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held-that the assessees had objected to the assessment before the Income-tax Officer on two grounds, namely, that the income was Dot the income of the assessees and that the income was exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a , as appeared from their letter dated January 22, 1947.

arguments.court_reasoning: Profits accrued to assessees from carrying on business under the scheme despite agreement to devote to charity.

arguments.claim: Profits did not form the income of the assessees because the scheme was completely under the control of the Deputy Commissioner and assessees were merely financiers and managers.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal was of the view that the scheme was the scheme of the Deputy Commissioner and companypletely under his companytrol that the assessees were merely the financiers and also managers under the Deputy Commissioner to carry out the scheme and that the assessees only helped to work the scheme. The Tribunal held that the profits that may have resulted from such working were number therefore theirs number represented their income

arguments.court_reasoning: Control by Deputy Commissioner does not prevent assessees from carrying on business; guarantee of payments indicates ownership; para 14 contemplates profits as theirs.

arguments.claim: Under s. 4, revenue must prove assessees received or deemed to have received income; no actual receipt and no deeming provision applied.

anchor.surface_text: On that reference the High Court held that under the charging section in the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, namely, s. 4, it was necessary for the revenue authorities to prove that the assessees received or should be deemed to have received income or profit from the scheme during the relevant period. It held that the asseess had number actually received any such income and further that the expression deemed to be received in that section only meant deemed by the provision of the Act to be received, and numbersuch provisions of the Act had been relied upon on behalf of the revenue authorities.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: e assessees and hence the necessity for this agreement so that the assessees might be made to spend them on charity. If, as the Tribunal thought, the

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court failed to appreciate real question was accrual of income, not receipt; s. 4 covers accrued income.

arguments.claim: High Court failed to appreciate the real question, which was whether income had accrued and whether profits formed the income of the assessees, not whether received or deemed received.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General companytends that the High Court failed to appreciate the real question. He says that the question was number whether income was received or deemed to be received but whether income had accrued and the point for decision was, as appeared from the judgment of the Tribunal, whether the profits formed the income of the assesses.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s the profits made by them would number change their character and cease to be the assessees income

arguments.court_reasoning: We agree with this criticism of the judgment of the High Court.

arguments.claim: Control of the scheme by the Deputy Commissioner does not prevent the working of the scheme by the assessees from being a business carried on by them.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal thought that since the scheme was companypletely under the companytrol of the Deputy Commissioner, the assessees companyld number be said to have carried on business by working the scheme. We are unable to see that the fact of the companytrol of the Deputy Commissioner can prevent the working of the scheme by the assessees from being a business carried on by them.

arguments.claim: Assessees agreed to carry on business in a certain manner under the scheme.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, it only companyes to this that the assessees had agreed to do business in a certain manner.

arguments.claim: Deputy Commissioner's guarantee of payments by Tehsildars indicates assessees were treated as owners of the business.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the Deputy Commissioner guaranteed the payment by the Tehsildars of the price due from them, to the assessees would indicate that the assessees were treated as the owners of the business. It would indicate that if there had been numbersuch guarantee, the loss due to the failure of the Tehsildars to pay their dues would have to be borne by the assessees.

arguments.claim: Assessees' alternative claim for exemption under s. 4(3)(i-a) implies they were carrying on a business.

anchor.surface_text: Again the claim, may be in the alternative, by the assessees for exemption under s. 4 3  i- a  would number arise unless the assessees were carrying on a business.

arguments.claim: Para 14 of the scheme contemplates profits resulting from the scheme belonging to assessees, with provision to devote to charity indicating ownership.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, para. 14 of the scheme which we, have earlier set out, clearly companytemplates profits resulting from the scheme. The provision that the profits would be devoted to charity to be decided by the Deputy Commissioner, would indicate that without it the profits would have been utilisable by the assessees. The profits belonged to the assessees and hence the necessity for this agreement so that the assessees might be made to spend them on charity.

arguments.claim: If profits were Government's, no necessity for para 14 directing expenditure on charity.

anchor.surface_text: If, as the Tribunal thought, the profits were of the Government, there was numbernecessity for the Government providing for the profits being expended on charity, for the Government if minded to do so, companyld have done it without such a provision.

arguments.claim: Agreement to devote profits to charity does not change their character as assessees' income.

anchor.surface_text: If they chose to agree by para. 14 to devote the profits to charity, that was their business the profits made by them would number change their character and cease to be the assessees income because they agreed to devote their income to charity.

arguments.claim: Assessees liable to tax on profits actually made, regardless of agreement not to make profits.

anchor.surface_text: We might also say that there is numberhing in the scheme which shows that the assessees had undertaken number to make any profits on the distribution work under the scheme they had only agreed to finance the scheme without receiving any interest or profit. Furthermore, since the assessees actually made the profits, they are liable to pay tax thereon whether they agreed number to make any profits or number.

arguments.claim: Assessees not made to pay out profits to charity.

anchor.surface_text: We wish also to point out that it is number the assessees case that they have been made to pay out the profits for any charity.

arguments.claim: Assessees not entitled to exemption under s. 4(3)(i-a) as scheme not carried on behalf of religious or charitable institution.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the assessees claim for exemption under s. 4 3  i-a , they are clearly number entitled to any. That claim of the assessees has number been accepted by any of the Courts below. Section 4 3  i-a  applies to income derived from business carried on on behalf of a religious and charitable institution when the income is applied solely to the purpose of the institution and the business is carried on in the manner provided.

arguments.claim: Once assessees made the profit, how they use it does not matter for taxability.

anchor.surface_text: It is enough to say that the scheme, companysidered as a business, was number carried on on behalf of any religious or charitable institution. Once it is held that the assessees made the profit, how they use it would number matter.

holdings.text: The profits resulting from the scheme were the income of the assessees which accrued to them and are assessable to income-tax in their hands.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we think that the profits were the profits of the assessees and they are liable to pay tax on them. With regard to the assessees claim for exemption under s. 4 3  i-a , they are clearly number entitled to any.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessees carried on business under scheme despite government control; para 14 contemplates their profits to be devoted to charity indicating ownership; guarantee of payments shows risk borne by them; actual profits made taxable regardless of agreement.

holdings.text: The assessees are not entitled to exemption under section 4(3)(i-a) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the assessees claim for exemption under s. 4 3  i-a , they are clearly number entitled to any. That claim of the assessees has number been accepted by any of the Courts below.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme not carried on behalf of any religious or charitable institution; exemption requires business on behalf of such institution with income applied solely thereto.

holdings.text: The control of the Deputy Commissioner over the scheme does not prevent the working of the scheme by the assessees from being a business carried on by them.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal thought that since the scheme was completely under the control of the Deputy Commissioner, the assessees could not be said to have carried on business by working the scheme. We are unable to see that the fact of the control of the Deputy Commissioner can prevent the working of the scheme by the assessees from being a business carried on by them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessees agreed to do business in specified manner; Deputy Commissioner's guarantee indicates assessees as owners bearing risk; alternative exemption claim implies business.

holdings.text: Paragraph 14 of the scheme indicates that the profits belonged to the assessees.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Provision to devote profits to charity shows they were assessees' to utilize otherwise; no need for such clause if government's profits.

holdings.text: Agreement to devote profits to charity does not change their character as income of the assessees.

anchor.surface_text: If they chose to agree by para. 14 to devote the profits to charity, that was their business the profits made by them would number change their character and cease to be the assessees income because they agreed to devote their income to charity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Profits accrue upon making; subsequent disposition does not alter accrual or taxability.

holdings.text: Assessees liable to tax on profits actually made regardless of agreement not to charge interest or profit.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Actual realization of profits triggers tax liability irrespective of prior no-profit intent.

holdings.text: The scheme considered as a business was not carried on behalf of any religious or charitable institution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No such institution involved; post-profit use irrelevant for exemption.

holdings.text: The High Court failed to appreciate that the real question was whether income had accrued to the assessees, not whether received or deemed received.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General contends that the High Court failed to appreciate the real question. He says that the question was number whether income was received or deemed to be received but whether income had accrued and the point for decision was, as appeared from the judgment of the Tribunal, whether the profits formed the income of the assesses. We agree with this criticism of the judgment of the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 4 charges on accrual; High Court misread as only receipt/deemed receipt.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we would answer both parts of the question framed, in-the affirmative. We hold that the profits were the income which accrued to the assessees and such income is assessable to income-tax and is number exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a .

outcome.relief_summary: Answered both parts of the question referred in the affirmative; held that profits accrued to the assessees as their income and are assessable to income-tax; not exempt under section 4(3)(i-a)

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons we think that the profits were the profits of the assessees and they are liable to pay tax on them. With regard to the assessees claim for exemption under s. 4 3  i-a , they are clearly number entitled to any.

In the result, we would answer both parts of the question framed, in-the affirmative. We hold that the profits were the income which accrued to the assessees and such income is assessable to income-tax and is number exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a .

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the assessees claim for exemption under s. 4 3  i-a , they are clearly number entitled to any. That claim of the assessees has number been accepted by any of the Courts below.

In the result, we would answer both parts of the question framed, in-the affirmative. We hold that the profits were the income which accrued to the assessees and such income is assessable to income-tax and is number exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a .

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal thought that since the scheme was completely under the control of the Deputy Commissioner, the assessees could not be said to have carried on business by working the scheme. We are unable to see that the fact of the control of the Deputy Commissioner can prevent the working of the scheme by the assessees from being a business carried on by them.

In the result, we would answer both parts of the question framed, in-the affirmative. We hold that the profits were the income which accrued to the assessees and such income is assessable to income-tax and is number exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a .

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General contends that the High Court failed to appreciate the real question. He says that the question was number whether income was received or deemed to be received but whether income had accrued and the point for decision was, as appeared from the judgment of the Tribunal, whether the profits formed the income of the assesses. We agree with this criticism of the judgment of the High Court.

In the result, we would answer both parts of the question framed, in-the affirmative. We hold that the profits were the income which accrued to the assessees and such income is assessable to income-tax and is number exempt from taxation under s. 4 3  i-a .
